properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A large low pressure system over Hudson Bay will bring significant rainfall to the south coast of Baffin Island on Thursday. In Kimmirut rain will begin overnight, accompanied by strong southeast winds gusting to 50 km/h. Rain, heavy at times, will continue through Thursday and Thursday night before ending early Friday morning. Total accumulations between 35-55 mm are expected by Friday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T11:42:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T19:43:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3836384465.2019
Area: Kimmirut
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical system Erin or its remnants will approach western Nova Scotia Thursday evening and then track into the Gulf of St. Lawrence Friday morning. Rain at times heavy will begin Thursday morning over southern sections of the province and then taper off by Friday morning. Total rainfall amounts of up to 60 millimetres are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T02:48:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T18:49:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1923897325.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and strong northerly winds continues to affect the Kivalliq coastline, with rainfall accumulations ranging from 15-20 mm as of early Wednesday afternoon. Further accumulations of 10-15 mm are expected before the rain tapers off late Thursday. Strong northerly winds gusting as high as 80 km/h are expected to continue tonight through Thursday as well. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system, which is bringing significant rain to the Churchill area, will continue to bring rain and strong gusty northerly winds to the region tonight and Thursday. Rainfall totals thus far up to 3:00 pm have reached 53 mm and a further 10 mm is expected before tapering off late Thursday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T12:44:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T20:45:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2275219999.2019
Area: Churchill
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Gusts reaching 100 kilometres per hour are expected this evening and overnight. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T11:43:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T19:44:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0838225663.2019
Area: Salluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. A fast moving low pressure system tracking across eastern Saskatchewan into west central Manitoba is supporting scattered thunderstorms this evening. Some of these thunderstorms could briefly reach severe thresholds. The severe thunderstorm threat will diminish late this evening as the low pressure system continues to track southeastwards across central and southern Manitoba. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T08:03:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T23:54:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2318475978.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. A low pressure system tracking rapidly through the northern Grain Belt of Saskatchewan is triggering scattered thunderstorms late this afternoon. Some of these thunderstorms could reach severe thresholds. The threat for severe thunderstorms will diminish this evening as the system tracks out of the province into Manitoba. This severe thunderstorm watch may be expanded eastwards early this evening as the system tracks southeastwards. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T05:06:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T21:26:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1215882692.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain, heavy at times, is forecast to begin over western New Brunswick tonight and spread to the east by Thursday morning as a trough of low pressure draws in moisture from Tropical Depression Erin. Total rainfall amounts may exceed 60 mm in areas of heaviest rain by the time it comes to an end late Thursday night or early Friday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Tropical Depression Erin. The next information statement will be issued by 03:00 a.m. ADT. Tropical Depression Erin is tracking northeastward toward the Maritimes. Erin is expected to transition to a post-tropical system well before it reaches southwestern Nova Scotia later Thursday evening. Erin will bring heavy rain to much of the region beginning Thursday and strong, gusty winds with its passage Thursday night into Friday morning. 1. Summary of basic information at 09:00 p.m. ADT. Location: Near 34.9 North 72.6 West. About distance 270 kilometres east of Cape Hatteras NC. Maximum sustained winds: 56 kilometres per hour. Present movement: North-northeast at 33 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 1003 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. Tropical Depression Erin is expected to transition to a post-tropical system by the time it enters Canadian waters on Thursday. Rain associated with a trough of low pressure approaching from the west will spread over the western Maritimes early Thursday morning. As Erin approaches later on Thursday, some of its moisture will feed into this trough and likely enhance the rain intensity associated with it. The heavier rain and strongest winds associated directly with post-tropical Erin should reach the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia later Thursday evening. a. Wind. Some gusty winds will likely accompany post-tropical Erin, especially to those areas just to the right of its track early Friday morning. At this time it is not expected that these winds will reach warning criteria (i.e. gusts to 90 km/h or higher), but could still be strong enough to cause isolated power outages and minor damage, especially given that trees are still in full leaf. b. Rainfall. The combination of Post-Tropical Erin and its interaction with the trough of low pressure crossing the region on Thursday will combine to produce significant rainfall. Rainfall will likely meet or exceed warning criteria (50 mm or more in 24 hours) in parts of the Maritimes, especially those areas just north and west of Erin's track. Some isolated locations in these areas could possibly see total rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm before the rain ends later Friday morning. c. Surge/Waves. At this time, warning level storm surge and coastal impacts from high waves are not expected. After midnight into Friday morning, waves near 4 metres will spread from west to east along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia and will break higher along the beaches. Rip currents will also be an issue, and the public should exercise caution near the coast. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. Gale warnings are in effect for the southwestern Maritimes marine waters, where gale force southerlies up to 35 knots are expected by Thursday evening. These gale warnings will likely be extended to adjacent marine areas for Friday near and along Erin's path through Canadian waters. Forecaster(s): Borgel/Mercer ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-30T05:48:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-28T23:49:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2158267407.2019

properties.Title: Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots, frequent lightning and hail of 1 to 2 centimetres are expected or occurring in the area. A line of thunderstorms is crossing Lake Winnipegosis this evening. Strong wind gusts in excess of 35 knots will accompany these thunderstorms. Activity should be fully east of the lake after 10 pm CDT. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical system Erin or its remnants will approach western Nova Scotia Thursday evening and then track across Prince Edward Island Friday morning. Rain at times heavy and gusty winds are expected as it moves through. Total rainfall amounts of up to 60 millimetres are possible, and rainfall warnings may be issued with future updates. Southeasterly wind gusts to 60 or 70 km/h are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical system Erin or its remnants will approach western Nova Scotia Thursday evening and then track into the Gulf of St. Lawrence Friday morning. Rain at times heavy and gusty winds are expected across most of Nova Scotia as it moves through. Total rainfall amounts of up to 60 millimetres are possible, with the heaviest rain expected northwest of Erin's track. Lesser amounts are expected across eastern areas of the province. Southeasterly wind gusts to 60 or 70 km/h are also possible. At this time, warning level storm surge and coastal impacts from high waves are not expected. After midnight into Friday morning, waves near 4 metres will spread from west to east along the Atlantic Coast of Nova Scotia and will break higher along the beaches. Rip currents will also be an issue, and the public should exercise caution near the coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-29T08:45:10-00:00
